page.title: 01LANDSCAPE 1
page.content: North of the River Greta grassy fields & hedges cover the drumlins from which farms take their names, e.g. Whaitber - wheat hill. South of the river pasture still predominates but there are patches of deciduous woodland. The River has cut through shale & clay and winds along its pebbly bed, under Burton Bridge then over rocky ledges between steep banks as it passes Greeta House. The hummocks & hollows on its southern side are the remains of coal and clay pits of the 18th & 19th centuries. The village is dominated by the tall spire of the church beside the village green close to the Norman castle mound at the end of High St. Four streets form a rectangle on the northern valley-side & are bordered by cottages & houses built mainly of sandstone.
